title: 107_hr3920
content: The "Rancher Preservation Act" is the short title of this Act. Section 13 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include special requirements regarding the black-tailed prairie dog. Section 13 of the Endangered Species Act of 1973 is amended to include requirements for using the best scientific and commercial data available when determining the status of the black-tailed prairie dog. This includes giving greater weight to empirical or peer-reviewed data and including population numbers in the evaluation. The Secretary cannot classify the black-tailed prairie dog as endangered or threatened without data obtained from the field. The Secretary must rely on field data for determining the status of the black-tailed prairie dog as endangered or threatened. Landowners' data collected through observation must be included in the decision-making process. Independent scientific review is required for any action regarding the species. The term 'qualified individual' refers to someone with expertise in biological sciences, specifically related to the black-tailed prairie dog or similar species. This expertise must be demonstrated through scientific literature publication or other means. The Secretary must appoint independent scientific reviewers who have no conflicts of interest, are not involved in any related petitions or determinations, and have no financial stake in opposing the action. Recommendations will be sought from the National Academy of Sciences to create a list of qualified reviewers. Before any final action, the Secretary must appoint 3 qualified independent scientific reviewers to assess the scientific information and analyses. The reviewers will not be subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act and will be compensated for their review. They must provide their opinion within 3 months. The Secretary must appoint 3 independent scientific reviewers to assess information on the black-tailed prairie dog. Within 3 months, they must provide their opinion, and the Secretary will consider their recommendations in the final determination. If the majority recommendation is not followed, an explanation must be provided. The report of peer reviewers must be included in the official record of the proposed action and available for public review. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections in the Act. Special requirements for black-tailed prairie dog are outlined in Section 13.
